message: Palestinian channels: An Israeli drone punched a hole in the dome of the Al-Abrar Mosque in the center of Rafah.

The Egyptian Foreign Ministry condemns the operation in Rafah. But what does it really mean?

The Egyptian Ministry of Foreign Affairs: 

"We strongly condemn the Israeli actions in Rafah and the takeover of the Palestinian side of the Rafah crossing. Egypt sees this as a risk to the lives of more than a million Palestinians who rely on the crossing. We call on Israel to exercise maximum restraint and "stay away from the edge of the precipice" - as it harms the efforts to reach a Hudna.

###
An untrained reader might wrongly think that Egypt truly opposes an Israeli military action in Rafah. I mean, it strongly condemned it...

But if we dig a little deeper, translate it into "spoken Middle Eastern", and read between the lines - there is no threat of concrete actions from the Egyptian side, no threat to trade agreements, or diplomatic relations, and certainly not to the peace agreements between the two countries.  

Egypt calls on Israel to exercise maximum restraint... This translates to - When you take down Hamas in Rafah, do it in a way that won't make us look bad. After all, we're not really doing anything to prevent you from doing so, but we still need to maintain our image as one of the leading countries in the Arab world...

The al-Sisi regime, which despises the Muslim Brotherhood and its Palestinian branch - Hamas, would be more than happy to see Hamas disappear from its border.

Meanwhile, there are quite a few complaints among Gazans on social media: Where has the Egyptian army gone? They're doing nothing to prevent Israel from acting in Rafah...

##
To summarize, the Egyptians are not that excited, and Hamas has not stopped the ceasefire talks. Now we understand just how idle all the threats to prevent a military operation in Rafah were.

This is an important lesson for the coming months of the war.

The movement of displaced Gazans from Rafah to Khan Yunis continues...

Some of the displaced people who left Rafah today are setting up tents near the ruins of their homes in Khan Yunis.

More ridicule from Fatah-affiliated channels: "Be quite!"

Attached is an old photo of the leader of Hamas in the Gaza Strip, Yahya Sinwar, in his good old days in an Israeli prison.

Fatah-affiliated channels are mocking Hamas:

Where have all the Hamas police officers gone?
Where are they? Why are they not protecting the people? Did they just all run away?

###
The fact that the IDF managed to take control of the Rafah crossing without almost no resistance is significant. 

Many Palestinian feel that Hamas has abandoned the battlefield, not living up to the hawkish statements from its spokespeople in recent weeks.

The strategic Rafah crossing fell into the hands of the Israelis almost without a fight.
What a pleasure to download such videos from channels pro-Iranian regime channels...
The swearing-in ceremony of Putin as President of Russia for another six years has begun.

The Lebanese Al-Mayadeen, citing a senior member of the "Palestinian Resistance":

"The taking over of the Rafah crossing threatens the ceasefire talks. Hamas sees it as a deliberate provocation with the aim of creating difficulties in negotiations."

###
And yet... despite past promises... Hamas has not stopped the negotiations.
This shows that it has a lot to lose from a full-out military operation in Rafah. 
Hamas was bluffing, and its hand was exposed.

Huge support for the president of Argentina, Javier Milei:

Elon Musk, one of the richest businessmen in the world, recommends investing in Argentina.

##
The Kerem Shalom crossing will likely remain closed for humanitarian aid... Hamas rocket fire puts truck drivers and others working at the crossing at risk.

ضاع معبر فيلادلفيا يا مصريين 💔

A Palestinian channel published the attached clip with the following caption:

"The Philadelphia (Rafah - AA) crossing is lost, O Egyptians 💔"

The military wing of Hamas: We launched rockets at the maneuvering forces inside the Rafah crossing.

##
Two things to note here:

1. Hamas officially admits that there are Israeli forces inside the Rafah crossing.
2. Hamas attacks the crossing with the aim of damaging it.
Additional photos published by the IDF spokesman from the Rafah crossing.

The IDF reports that it had eliminated 20 terrorists and uncovered three operational tunnel shafts as part of the operation in Rafah.

Additionally, the IDF spokesman published footage of Israeli forces entering and taking control of the Rafah crossing compound.

Honestly, these are exciting sights. The Rafah crossing is the crossing through which Hamas released some of the Israeli hostages during November's Hudna. Now it's under Israeli control. 

White and blue flags - looks better this way.

Here's something important to note:

The ground operation in Rafah has begun, there is no disputing that.
There are significant achievements on the ground - the control of the Rafah crossing, there is no dispute over that either.

Despite all of this and despite explicit and public promises from senior Hamas officials that action in Rafah will cause the negotiations to stop - Hamas has not announced as of now the suspension of talks for a ceasefire deal.

This is important. The military pressure works in Israel's favor in the negotiations. This is how negotiations are conducted in the Middle East. Israel didn't play into the hands of Hamas, negotiating from a position of weakness, but rather took initiative and action - forcing Hamas, which remained stubborn in its demands throughout the recent round of talks, into a worse position to negotiate from.
Displaced residents from eastern Rafah start moving to Khan Yunis, following the beginning of the Israeli military operation in the area.

The Shiite militias in Iraq have increased the number of announcements about alleged attacks on Israeli territory.

Last night, the militias announced that they had attacked the Yehonatan and Jordan bases (in the Golan) with suicide drones. They also claim to have attacked the Sapir base early this morning.

The multitude of announcements comes against the background of the progress of the ground operation in Rafah.

The IDF spokesman announced this morning the death of two reservists, major Dan Kamkagi and major Natan Hertz, from the 6551 patrol battalion.

The two were killed in yesterday's suicide drone attack in the Metula area.

May their memory be a blessing.

The Palestinians, for their part, report 15 casualties as a result of IDF airstrikes on several houses east and west of Rafah.

Given the number of attacks by the IDF last night and considering that "the ground operation in Rafah has begun", this is a very small number of casualties. One possible reason for this could be the evacuation leaflets that have been dropped in the area in recent days.

Attached is footage of some of last night's attacks in Rafah, as photographed from the Egyptian side of the border.

A major Hamas oxygen pipeline has been cut off - currently, the IDF controls the Rafah crossing.

The IDF holds and fully controls one of Hamas's main power sources in recent months - the Gazan side of the Rafah crossing.

The crossing is closed to passenger traffic, and the commercial crossing is also shut for trucks carrying goods.

The attached photos are circulating on most Palestinian and Arab channels - everyone is witnessing this development!

This is an important mental and military achievement. The Israeli flag flies at the Rafah crossing.

Equally important to note is that there was no significant resistance or fighting from Hamas, and that this objective was achieved within hours of the operation's announcement.

Well done.

Some geographic data about Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip:
1. The distance from the border with Israel to the beach in Rafah in a straight line is 12 km.

2. The distance from the Israeli border to the Rafah crossing is about 3 km.

3. The distance from the border of Israel to the line of the eastern neighborhoods of Rafah is also about three kilometers. In between there is an area that is not urban and has almost no residential buildings - there is also the destroyed Gaza airport, which in recent years has become an area for pirate car races and camel races.

The neighborhoods of A-Salam and Janinah in East Rafah (the 3 km line) are the first urban areas that the IDF's maneuvering forces will encounter in East Rafah.

The Palestinians report dead and wounded in an Israeli airstrike on a building in the Tal a-Sultan neighborhood in West Rafah (marked with a red circle).

I also marked with a blue arrow a possible path taken by the Israeli tanks that arrived near the Rafah crossing, according to the earlier Palestinian report.
According to another Palestinian report from the last few minutes, 3 IDF tanks have arrived at a distance of about 200 meters from the Rafah crossing and they are firing at buildings in the crossing.

Journalists in Rafah are reporting heavy artillery fire from the IDF now towards the area surrounding the Rafah and Kerem Shalom crossing complexes as well as towards the A-Salam and Jeninah neighborhoods in East Rafah. There is also an air attack on targets in a-Tanor neighborhood, also in East Rafah.

##
There are still no reports of a significant advance of maneuvering forces into Rafah and according to some the sources of the maneuvering forces are not far from the border fence, still in open areas and not in urban areas.
Some residents of Rafah do not care about the fact that Israel did not agree to a hudna. They went out to celebrate Hamas's announcement of accepting the terms of the ceasefire even late at night.
Flares in the east of Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip, moments ago.
Airstrikes in Janineh, eastern Rafah.

Despite Hamas's offer being far from meeting Israel's crucial demands, Israel will send work crews to the mediators to maximize the possibility of reaching an agreement acceptable to Israel.

(Israeli - AA) tank movement under heavy artillery cover.

Knesset MK Mansour Abbas: We will provide a safety net to any political party that formulates a ceasefire deal in Gaza. It is a moral obligation to end suffering that has lasted for 7 months.

Source: Muhammad Majadala
In the same breath, the question of disarming Hamas should also come up. This too as part of the agreement.
Against the background of Hamas's agreement - chants in praise of Muhammad Deif, the head of Hamas's military wing, in the square of the Shuhada al-Aqsa hospital in Deir al-Balah.

An important question to ask tonight:
What does the ceasefire agreement say about the continued presence of Hamas in the Gaza Strip and its continued rule?

Will senior Hamas officials finish their journey in the Strip and be deported or will they stay in the Strip and renew their control over the Strip?

This is a question that Israel should ask itself and also present this question to the Americans.

If the war ends before the second phase of the deal and before the release of all the abductees, what will happen to senior Hamas officials who are in the Strip?

This should appear in the agreement.

Khalil al-Hayya, Yahya Sinwar's deputy, in an interview with Al Jazeera:

We agreed that there would be a temporary ceasefire in the first phase of the transaction, but before the start of the second phase of the transaction (which includes the release of the kidnapped IDF soldiers - AA) a permanent ceasefire would be announced.

The mediators promised that President Biden would be a clear guarantor of the implementation of the agreement.
The solution to all these complications is transparency. Publish the proposals officially. This will prevent deals being made in the dark.

Hamas knows that its public announcement will direct all the international pressure from it towards the Israeli government. 

Hamas knows that the announcement will create pressure on the Israeli government at home, just as the recent videos of the abductees did.

Through the announcement, Hamas hopes to neutralize the wheels of action in Rafah that have begun to move and stall the Israeli momentum.

If you are confused about the issue of the agreement with Hamas, I will simplify the matter for you:

The root of the contention is the issue of a permanent ceasefire, or whether the fighting will resume after the hudna.

In the rest of the details there are no major disputes.

Hamas will not agree to sign an agreement that does not guarantee it a permanent ceasefire, and Israel will not agree to sign an agreement that will prevent it from resuming fighting after the hudna. It's one or the other.

In the middle are the USA, Qatar and Egypt who are trying, in my opinion, fraudulently, to find a way to say yes to both sides. There is a one and a zero here. If one side gets what it wants, the other doesn't.
The US is trying to guarantee Hamas behind Israel's back a permanent ceasefire, even though Israel is not ready for it. Hence the sensitivity created by Netanyahu's public statement yesterday regarding the continuation of the war. As a result, Hamas is not satisfied with the American guarantees... which conflict with the continuation of the war as Israel wants.

Get out from behind the curtain. Present to the public the proposal to which you agreed and present the proposal to which Hamas agreed.

The Israeli public has the right to see the details of a deal that will affect their future in the State of Israel and judge for themselves.

Against the backdrop of the announcement by Hamas of its agreement to a ceasefire, Gaza residents took to the streets to celebrate.

If the pressure from the operation in Rafah did the job and made Hamas flexible, perhaps more pressure could improve the terms of the deal...
This is how negotiations are done in the Middle East. Under fire.

Hamas is shifting the public and international pressure in Israel's direction.
Now we have to wait to understand what exactly Hamas agreed to and what guarantees they received.

I have no grand words to write to you for Holocaust Day.

Just this: be good to each other. Look for what unites us. This is the secret of our strength. Together we can do anything. Against all of our enemies. This week, between Holocaust Day and Memorial Day, write only good things. No hate, no loathing. And if it's difficult then you can not write anything at all. It will only do you and all of us good.

IDF Spokesperson: The IDF and ISA struck a Hamas command and control center located  in an UNRWA complex in central Gaza which served as a staging ground for multiple attacks against IDF troops and humanitarian efforts

Following precise IDF and ISA intelligence, IAF fighter jets struck a Hamas command and control center in the central Gaza Strip which served as central terrorist infrastructure. The strike was carefully planned and carried out using precise munition in order to minimize harm to uninvolved civilians. 

The command and control center was used as a staging ground for multiple attacks on IDF troops located in Gaza's central corridor in recent weeks. Furthermore, the forward operations base was used to carry out attacks on humanitarian efforts, which aims to increase the distribution of humanitarian aid to Gazan civilians.

In addition, Hamas oversaw the supply of weapons to dozens of Hamas terrorists from inside the command and control center, including those located and operating inside underground terror tunnels. 

Hamas intentionally positioned the command and control position within the vicinity of an active UNRWA location, jeopardizing the Gazan civilians taking refuge there.

The Hamas terrorist organization systematically exploits the civilian population and institutions as human shields for their terrorist activities against the State of Israel.

As a result of the strike, the Hamas’ command and control center located in the UNRWA complex is no longer operational.
